questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Renal calculus of > 4 cm of the Staghorn type. What is the best management modality in this case? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy

 

PCNL is the preferred treatment for large and complex kidney stones, especially Staghorn calculi. It involves making a small incision in the patient's back to access the kidney directly. A nephroscope is then used to remove or break up the stone. PCNL is highly effective in managing large stones like Staghorn calculi.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ESWL (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy): ESWL is a non-invasive procedure that uses shock waves to break up kidney stones into smaller pieces, making them easier to pass. While ESWL is effective for smaller kidney stones (<2cm), it may not be as successful for very large and complex Staghorn calculi.

 

Option C. Ureteroscopic removal: Ureteroscopy is a procedure that involves inserting a thin, flexible tube (ureteroscope) through the urethra and bladder to reach the stone in the kidney or upper urinary tract. While it can be effective for ureteric stones, it may not be the best choice for Staghorn calculi, especially those larger than 4 cm.

 

Option D. Open pyelolithotomy: This may be done in cases where PCNL fails or is contra-indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is the gold standard for the management of large and complex stones, like in this case.

 

PCNL is indicated in

 

  • Staghorn calculi - Stone >2 cm
  • Multiple stones - >1 cm

 

ESWL is only 45-60% efficacious in the treatment of large stones. Also, it causes frequent complications including pain, hydronephrosis, fever, and occasional urosepsis, due to difficulties in the passage of stone particles, especially when there has been insufficient disintegration.

 

Complications of percutaneous nephrolithotomy include:

 

  • Hemorrhage from the punctured renal parenchyma
  • Perforation of the collecting system with extravasation of saline irrigant
  • Perforation of the colon or pleural cavity during placement of the percutaneous track

questions.text: A partogram of a woman in labor is shown below. Oxytocin infusion has been administered. Mark the best management for the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

The above partogram suggests that the woman has cephalopelvic disproportion, for which the management would be to perform an emergency caesarean section.

 

According to the above given partogram, findings are

 

  • Cervix is fully dilated
  • Moulding is 2+ = Sutures are overlapped but reducible
  • Station is 3+
  • Oxytocin infusion administered.
  • Uterine contractions - Adequate.
  • Amniotic fluid - M = Meconium-stained fluid
  • Fetal heart rate – Deceleration = Baby is in distress
  • Descent: Head is 3/5th palpable; this means that an instrument cannot be applied. For either forceps of vacuum to be applied, the head should not be palpable per abdomen.

 

In case of fetal distress, the management is an emergency cesarean section, not instrumental delivery or elective cesarean section.

 

Cephalopelvic disproportion means there is a disproportion in the fetal head and pelvis. It could be due to a Contracted pelvis or large baby (Macrosomia)

 

Degrees of Disproportion

 

  1. Severe degree contracted pelvis: Obstetric conjugate < 7.5 cm
  2. Moderate degree: Obstetric conjugate between 7.5 to 9.5 cm
  3. Borderline pelvis: Obstetric conjugate measures between 9.5 to 10 cm

 

Obstructed labor is one where despite good uterine contractions, the progressive descent of the presenting part is arrested due to mechanical obstruction. Cephalopelvic disproportion and contracted pelvis are the common causes.

 

A cesarean section at term is should be done in these cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Forceps-assisted delivery: Not suitable because the head is still palpable per abdomen and forceps cannot be applied.

 

Option B. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Not appropriate due to the same reason as above; the head is still palpable per abdomen.

 

Option C. Oxytocin infusion: Oxytocin infusion is already being administered, and increasing or continuing it won't resolve the issue of cephalopelvic disproportion and fetal distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of cephalopelvic disproportion and fetal distress, as indicated by a partogram, the management should be an emergency cesarean section.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe, sudden-onset right-sided flank pain radiating towards the groin. She has a history of chronic constipation and frequently uses laxatives to manage her symptoms. On physical examination, her abdomen is soft with mild tenderness, and there is no guarding or rebound tenderness. Laboratory results show hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and elevated urine PH. A non-contrast CT scan of the abdomen reveals multiple small, radiolucent stones in the right kidney. What is the most likely type of kidney stone in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ammonium urate

 

Explanation:

 

Ammonium urate stones are associated with chronic laxative abuse, which leads to metabolic disturbances such as hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. Laxative abuse results in chronic diarrhea and loss of bicarbonate, contributing to an alkaline urinary environment that favors the formation of ammonium urate stones. These stones are formed when ammonia combines with uric acid in alkaline urine, making this stone type particularly linked to altered urinary pH caused by laxative use.

 

Pathophysiology: Chronic laxative use causes dehydration, hypokalemia, and significant loss of bicarbonate, resulting in metabolic alkalosis. This alkaline state promotes the solubility of ammonia in urine, leading to the formation of ammonium urate stones. The altered urinary pH and electrolyte disturbances create a favorable condition for these specific stones to develop.

 

Clinical Features: Patients typically present with symptoms of kidney stones, such as severe flank pain and hematuria. A history of laxative abuse, chronic diarrhea, and associated metabolic findings such as hypokalemia and elevated urine pH are critical clues pointing towards ammonium urate stones.

 

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is made through imaging, such as a non-contrast CT, which identifies radiolucent stones. Laboratory findings supporting the diagnosis include hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and high urine pH, all contributing factors to ammonium urate stone formation.

 

Management: Management focuses on addressing the underlying cause of stone formation by discontinuing laxative use, correcting electrolyte imbalances, and ensuring proper hydration. Preventive strategies include managing gastrointestinal conditions and monitoring urinary pH and electrolytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium phosphate: This option is incorrect because calcium phosphate stones are usually associated with hyperparathyroidism of renal tubular acidosis. They form in alkaline urine but are not related to chronic laxative use.

 

Option C. Xanthine: This option is incorrect because xanthine stones result from a genetic metabolic disorder called xanthinuria. These stones form due to high xanthine levels in urine and are unrelated to laxative abuse.

 

Option D. Mixed calcium-magnesium phosphate: This option is incorrect as mixed calcium-magnesium phosphate stones, also known as infection stones, form in the presence of urease-producing bacteria during urinary tract infections. They are not associated with chronic diarrhea or metabolic alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ammonium urate stones are strongly associated with chronic laxative abuse, leading to dehydration, metabolic alkalosis, and an alkaline urinary environment. Recognizing the metabolic and clinical consequences of chronic gastrointestinal disturbances is essential for diagnosing and managing nephrolithiasis related to laxative abuse.

questions.text: Management of hyperkalemia includes all except : (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Magnesium sulphate

 

Magnesium sulfate is not typically used for the treatment of hyperkalemia. It is more commonly used in the management of eclampsia in pregnant women and for its neuromuscular blocking effects in various other medical conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

The management of hyperkalemia typically involves interventions that stabilize the cardiac membrane, shift potassium into cells, and remove potassium from the body. Common treatments include:

 

Option A. Calcium gluconate: Which stabilizes the cardiac membrane and does not lower potassium levels but protects the heart from the effects of hyperkalemia.

 

Option B. Insulin drip: Often accompanied by glucose, which drives potassium back into cells, thereby lowering its serum concentration.

 

Option  C. Salbutamol nebulization: A beta-agonist that promotes the movement of potassium into cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of hyperkalemia

 

  • Calcium gluconate- reduces plasma K+ concentration by redistribution in cells rapidly
  • Insulin- lowers plasma K+ concentration by moving potassium intracellular, insulin dose used – 10units of IV regular insulin f/b 50ml of 50%dextrose
  • Salbutamol
  • Cation exchange resins, diuretics, dialysis.

choices.text: Documentation of injuries and examination findings

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl, accompanied by her mother, is brought to a lady police sub-inspector, alleging a history of sexual violence that occurred two days ago. The next course of action for the registered medical practitioner would be?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Take a detailed history

 

The next course of action involves the registered medical practitioner gathering a comprehensive medical history.

 

The registered medical professional must conduct a comprehensive medical history review and obtain informed consent before proceeding with the examination. If the individual declines the examination, a well-documented informed refusal must be obtained, clearly explaining the potential consequences of their decision.

 

During the examination process, the medical practitioner should gather necessary specimens, preserve any relevant clothing, and meticulously document all injuries and findings. It is essential to provide free medical treatment and conduct pregnancy testing for all victims of sexual assault, as mandated by law under section 357-C of CrPc. Additionally, the police must be notified accordingly.

 

Other Options

 

Option B: Preserve clothing: Preserving clothing is essential for forensic evidence but should follow after taking a detailed history to ensure the context is understood and evidence is collected appropriately.

 

Option C: Take consent for genital examination: Taking consent for a genital examination is critical but must come after obtaining a detailed history to ensure the examination is conducted respectfully and with full understanding of the context.

 

Option D: Documentation of injuries and examination findings: Documentation of injuries and examination findings is vital for forensic and medical records but should be done after taking a detailed history and obtaining informed consent.

 

Educational Objective

 

In cases of alleged sexual violence, the initial and crucial step for the registered medical practitioner is to take a detailed history from the victim.

choices.text: Stop warfarin and start LMWH.
Stop warfarin and start heparin.
Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with a prosthetic valve replacement for mitral stenosis is on warfarin therapy 4mg/ day. What is the appropriate next step in management. (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stop warfarin and start LMWH.

 

Explanation:

 

Stop warfarin and start LMWH: Warfarin is teratogenic and has a significant risk of causing warfarin embryopathy, particularly in doses greater than 5mg per day. In pregnancy, it is recommended to change warfarin to low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) or unfractionated heparin (UFH) in the first trimester, especially if the warfarin dose exceeds 5 mg/day. After 13 weeks, it can be switched back to warfarin until delivery. Near delivery, warfarin should again be replaced by LMWH or UFH to manage the risk of bleeding complications during delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stop warfarin and start heparin: This option is partially correct as it aligns with the practice of switching from warfarin to a safer anticoagulant near delivery. However, the preferred anticoagulant in this situation is LMWH due to its predictable pharmacokinetics and ease of administration.

 

Option C. Continue warfarin: This is incorrect because continuing warfarin at 36 weeks of gestation poses significant risks of fetal hemorrhage and warfarin embryopathy. It is essential to switch to a safer anticoagulant like LMWH or UFH close to delivery.

 

Option D. Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin: While this option includes stopping warfarin and starting LMWH, which is correct, the addition of aspirin is only indicated in women who are at a very high risk of thrombosis. The general recommendation does not include aspirin unless there is a specific high-risk indication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin should be replaced by low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) or unfractionated heparin (UFH) near delivery to manage the risks associated with its teratogenic effects and potential complications during delivery.

 

Ref: Page no 2404, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of pain, photophobia and redness of the right eye since 2 days. He gave a history of injury by a leaf, to the same eye, 5 days back. What is the likely diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fungal corneal ulcer

 

The given clinical situation suggests that it is a fungal corneal ulcer.

 

Fungal corneal ulcer is usually caused by trauma with vegetative or organic matter or injury by animal tail.

 

A very characteristic feature of fungal corneal ulcer is that the Signs are much more than Symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior uveitis: This involves inflammation of the middle layer of the eye, which can cause pain and redness but does not involve the specific corneal changes seen in fungal ulcers.

 

Option B. Conjunctivitis: An inflammation or infection of the outer membrane of the eyeball and the inner eyelid, typically causing redness and discharge, not the specific features of a corneal ulcer.

 

Option D. Corneal laceration: While also a result of trauma, lacerations would generally present immediately post-injury with sharp, distinct cuts, rather than developing signs of infection such as those described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fungal corneal ulcer should be considered when a patient presents with eye symptoms following trauma involving vegetative or organic material. Key diagnostic features include a greyish-white ulcer with feathery margins, potentially accompanied by a hypopyon, and absence of corneal vascularization.

questions.text: Which type of graph is used to illustrate studies on healthcare and disease prevalence in a population? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Ishikawa diagram/Fish bone diagram

 

Explanation

 

Ishikawa Diagram/Fish Bone Diagram/ Cause & Effect Diagram:

 

Description: A visual tool that helps trace a problem’s cause back to its roots, creating a branched diagram that looks like a fishbone.

 

Application: Used to identify, explore, and display the possible causes of a particular problem, particularly useful in quality control and prevention strategies in healthcare.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Bar Diagram:

 

Description: Bar diagrams use bars of varying lengths to represent data. Each bar corresponds to a category with a specific quantity.

 

Application: Useful for comparing quantities across different categories, such as the number of cases in different disease categories or patient counts in various demographic groups.

 

Option B. Histogram:

 

Description: A histogram is similar to a bar chart but is used for continuous quantitative data divided into bins or intervals. It helps in understanding the distribution of data.

 

Application: Commonly used to show the distribution of a dataset, such as the age distribution of patients suffering from a specific disease or the distribution of blood pressure readings in a population.

 

Option C. Multiple Regression Model:

 

Description: Not a graph, but a statistical technique that models the relationship between a dependent variable and multiple independent variables.

 

Application: Used to predict outcomes based on several variables, such as predicting patient outcomes based on age, treatment type, and pre-existing conditions.

 

Educational objectives : Fishbone diagrams are instrumental in root cause analysis, helping healthcare teams systematically investigate the contributory factors leading to health issues or outbreaks.

questions.text: A patient complains of neck stiffness and severe headache. The CT image shown below is suggestive of which of the following conditions?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with neck stiffness and severe headache with CT showing blood in the basal cistern suggests towards the diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is an extra axial intracranial hemorrhage and denotes the presence of blood within the subarachnoid space. NCCT shows the hyperdense “star of death” appearance.

 

The modified Fisher scale is a grading method for SAH as seen on non-contrast CT (NCCT). The Hunt and Hess scale is used to describe the severity of SAH and to predict survival.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Meningitis can also present with neck stiffness and headache. NCCT would be normal. CE-MRI shows thickened enhancing meninges.

 

Option C: Intraparenchymal hemorrhage is acute accumulation of blood within the parenchyma of the brain and on CT scan a hyperdense collection of blood, often with surrounding hypodense edema.

 

Option D: Hemorrhagic stroke is a broader classification and usually indicated IC bleed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage is a critical condition indicated by CT findings of blood in the subarachnoid space, presenting clinically with rapid onset headache and neck stiffness. It requires immediate medical attention and further evaluation with grading scales like the modified Fisher scale to assess severity and guide treatment.

questions.text: After performing a midline laparotomy, you need to suture the incision. What length of suture material will you choose? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4x incision length

 

Explanation

 

According to Jenkins' rule, the optimal ratio of suture length to wound length is 4:1. This ensures that the suture bites are appropriately spaced and not too tight or too far apart, which helps in effective wound closure and healing. If less length than this is used, the suture bites may be too far apart or too tight, and the converse applies if more length than this is used.

 

Other options

 

Option A. 2x incision length: Using a suture length that is twice the incision length may result in suture bites that are too tight or too far apart, potentially leading to ineffective wound closure.

 

Option C. 6x incision length: Using a suture length that is six times the incision length may lead to excessive suture material and overly dense suturing, which is not necessary and can complicate the procedure.

 

Option D. 8x incision length: Using a suture length that is eight times the incision length is excessive and unnecessary for effective wound closure.

 

Educational Objectives: The optimal suture length to wound length ratio for effective wound closure, as per Jenkins' rule, is 4:1. This ratio ensures proper spacing and tension of the sutures.

choices.text: Includes breathing, movements, tone, and Amniotic fluid volume
Can tell us about fetal outcome and fetal pH
Score is inconsistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages
Score <4: fetal pH <7.2; Score 0: 100% fetal acidemia

questions.text: All are true about biophysical profile (BPP) except? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Score is inconsistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages

 

Explanation:

 

  • BPP score is not inconsistent with fetal pH, but has a direct linear relationship with fetal pH and thus can be used to predict fetal acidemia.
  • BPP is a multi-parametric, screening test to assess uteroplacental insufficiency.
  • It consists of five components/ variables and the observations are made in a 30 minutes time period.
  • The Biophysical Profile has 5 components and is scored using Manning score
    • NST
    • Amniotic Fluid Volume
    • Fetal movement
    • Fetal Tone
    • Fetal Breathing

   

 

  • A low Manning score correlates with fetal hypoxia
  • Narcotics and sedatives can significantly lower the score
  • A BPP score of 0 was almost invariably associated with significant fetal acidemia, whereas a normal score of 8 or 10 was associated with normal pH.
  • An equivocal test result—a score of 6—was a poor predictor of an abnormal outcome. A drop in the BPP score from 2 or 4 down to 0 more accurately predicted an abnormal fetal outcome.
  • Overall, BPP scores provided poor sensitivity to predict cord blood pH
  • The Modified BPP has 2 components
    • NST
    • AFI

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Includes breathing, movements, tone, and Amniotic fluid volume: This statement is true. The BPP includes assessments of fetal breathing, movements, tone, and the Amniotic fluid volume as part of its evaluation.

 

Option B. Can tell us about fetal outcome and fetal pH: This statement is true. The BPP score helps predict fetal outcome and provides an indication of fetal pH, reflecting the level of fetal distress.

 

Option D. Score <4: fetal pH <7.2; Score 0: 100% fetal acidemia: This statement is true. A BPP score of less than 4 correlates with a fetal pH <7.2, and a score of 0 is almost invariably associated with significant fetal acidemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Biophysical Profile (BPP) provides a consistent prediction of fetal pH and outcome, with a lower score correlating with increased risk of fetal acidemia.

 

Ref: Page no 999, Williams Obstetric 26th edition

questions.text: An 88-year-old male presented to the emergency department with the sudden onset of severe epigastric pain. On physical examination, she had a temperature of 101.44° F, a pulse of 115 bpm and a blood pressure of 125/72 mm of Hg. Abdomen was tender & rigid. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pneumoperitoneum

 

Explanation:

 

The presence of free gas under the right diaphragm in the X-ray. This is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum.

 

  • C/F: Acute abdominal pain, rigidity, tenderness, guarding.
  • Most sensitive X-ray: CXR-PA erect.
  • Most sensitive Ix: CECT with oral contrast.
  • Next step: Resuscitation with IV fluids, Exploratory laparotomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: Involves air in the pleural space, not under the diaphragm. The clinical presentation and X-ray findings do not support this diagnosis.

 

Option C. Subdiaphragmatic abscess: Typically presents with localized pain and fever, but X-ray findings would be more consistent with an abscess formation rather than free air.

 

Option D. Intestinal obstruction: While it might present with abdominal pain and distension, free air under the diaphragm is not a characteristic finding unless there is a concurrent bowel perforation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pneumoperitoneum is a critical finding indicating a potential perforation of the gastrointestinal tract, requiring immediate assessment and surgical intervention. This diagnosis is supported by the presence of free air under the diaphragm seen on the X-ray.

choices.text: Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain

questions.text: A young boy from high altitude came with fever and weakness and had the following reports - Hemoglobin 17 g%, TLC is 21,000 with neutrophils 25, lymphocytes 30, eosinophils 5, myelocytes and metamyelocytes 40 in peripheral smear. Next step in the investigation should be: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Erythropoietin levels

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia (Hb>16 g/dL). Erythropoietin levels should be determined to differentiate primary from secondary forms.

 

Polycythemia vera (PCV) is characterized by increased marrow production of red cells, granulocytes, and platelets (panmyelosis), but it is the increase in red cells (polycythemia) that is responsible for most of the clinical symptoms. PCV must be differentiated from relative polycythemia resulting from hemoconcentration and other causes of absolute polycythemia. PCV is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase JAK2.

 

In PCV the progenitor cells have markedly decreased requirements for erythropoietin and other hematopoietic growth factors due to constitutive JAK2 signaling. Accordingly, serum erythropoietin levels in PCV are very low, whereas secondary forms of absolute polycythemia have high erythropoietin levels.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Philadelphia chromosome: The Philadelphia chromosome is associated with Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) and would not be the primary investigation in a case where polycythemia is suspected.

 

Option B. JAK mutation: While JAK2 mutations are common in Polycythemia Vera, erythropoietin levels should be assessed first to differentiate between primary and secondary causes. If primary polycythemia is suspected after assessing erythropoietin levels, testing for JAK2 mutations would be the next step.

 

Option D. Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain: This test would be more relevant if there is a need to assess bone marrow fibrosis or other marrow abnormalities, but it is not the first-line investigation in the context of suspected polycythemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected polycythemia, particularly in patients from high-altitude areas, erythropoietin levels should be assessed first to differentiate between primary and secondary causes of polycythemia.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cortans pathologic basis of disease, Page No.  1161, 1242

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankyloblepharon

 

Ankyloblepharon is a condition where the upper and lower eyelids become attached to each other. This can happen as a congenital anomaly or due to adhesions that form during the healing process of traumatic wounds, ulcers, or chemical burns affecting the eyelid margins. Treatment involves removing the adhesions between the eyelid margins. In cases where adhesions extend to the angles, epithelial grafts should be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Symblepharon is the adhesion between the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva in which the eyelids become adherent to the eyeball.

 

The image given below shows symblepharon.

 

 

Option C: Congenital blepharophimosis is a condition in which the extent of the palpebral fissure is decreased. It can be congenital or acquired and is due to a vertical skin fold at the lateral canthus. No treatment is required. In some cases, canthoplasty is done.

 

 

Option D: Congenital ptosis is a condition present since birth and is characterized by drooping of one or both upper eyelids due to developmental defects or weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) muscle. The affected individuals may also have lid lag on downward gaze. The most common treatment for congenital ptosis is surgical correction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ankyloblepharon involves the fusion of the eyelid margins, which can be congenital or acquired, and requires surgical intervention to correct the adhesion and restore normal eyelid function and appearance.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is found unconscious on the side of the road after a high-speed motorcycle collision. On arrival at the emergency department, he does not respond to verbal commands. When painful stimuli are applied, he opens his eyes, flexes his right arm, and localizes the painful stimulus with his left arm. He does not speak or make any vocal sounds. Based on these findings, what is his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 8

 

Explanation:

 

The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) assesses a patient's level of consciousness based on eye, verbal, and motor responses. In this scenario, the patient’s GCS score is calculated as follows:

 

Eye-opening to pain = 2 points, no verbal response = 1 point, and localizing painful stimulus with one limb while flexing another = 5 points for motor response. Thus, the total GCS score is 2 (Eye) + 1 (Verbal) + 5 (Motor) = 8.

 

Detailed Scoring:

 

  • Eye Response (E):
    • 4 = Spontaneous
    • 3 = To voice
    • 2 = To pain
    • 1 = None
  • Verbal Response (V):
    • 5 = Oriented
    • 4 = Confused speech
    • 3 = Inappropriate words
    • 2 = Incomprehensible sounds
    • 1 = None
  • Motor Response (M):
    • 6 = Obeys commands
    • 5 = Localizes pain
    • 4 = Withdraws to pain
    • 3 = Abnormal flexion (decorticate)
    • 2 = Abnormal extension (decerebrate)
    • 1 = No response

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is a critical tool used in trauma and neurological assessment to evaluate a patient's level of consciousness. Accurate scoring of eye, verbal, and motor responses helps guide clinical management and predict patient outcomes in cases of head trauma or altered mental status.

questions.text: Child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be Zellweger syndrome. Which among the following accumulates in brain in this condition?(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Long chain fatty acid

 

Zellweger syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder. It occurs due to defective oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA). Peroxisomal enzymes are produced; but their entry into peroxisome is denied. This leads to insufficient oxidation of VLCFA. Accumulation of VLCFA in CNS causes neurological impairment and death in childhood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose:

  • Function: Primary energy source for the brain.
  • Relevance: Accumulation is not characteristic of Zellweger syndrome but is more relevant in conditions like glycogen storage diseases or diabetes.

 

Option B. Lactic acid:

  • Function: Produced during anaerobic metabolism.
  • Relevance: Accumulation is associated with mitochondrial disorders or lactic acidosis, not Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option D. Triglycerides:

  • Function: Stored form of energy in adipose tissue.
  • Relevance: Accumulation in the brain is not characteristic of Zellweger syndrome; rather, it is associated with lipid storage diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zellweger syndrome leads to the accumulation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) in the brain due to defective peroxisomal oxidation, resulting in severe neurological impairment and early death in affected children.

questions.text: Match the postmortem findings and their time of appearance:(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

Postmortem changes occur in a sequential manner and can be used to estimate the time since death. The matching of these findings with their respective times of appearance is as follows:

 

  1. Adipocere formation
    • Time of appearance: 8-10 days
    • Explanation: Adipocere, also known as grave wax, is a postmortem change that occurs when body fat undergoes a transformation into a waxy substance in a moist environment. This process typically begins around 8-10 days after death.
  2. Relaxation of urethral sphincter
    • Time of appearance: 24 hrs
    • Explanation: After death, muscle relaxation, including the relaxation of the urethral sphincter, occurs due to the cessation of neural activity and muscle tone, typically around 24 hours postmortem.
  3. Marbling of veins
    • Time of appearance: 2-3 days
    • Explanation: Marbling refers to the appearance of greenish-black discoloration along the veins due to the breakdown of hemoglobin and the production of hydrogen sulphide gas by bacteria. This occurs approximately 2-3 days after death.
  4. Liquefaction of tissues
    • Time of appearance: 4-5 days
    • Explanation: Tissue liquefaction is a stage of decomposition where tissues start to break down into a liquid form. This process typically begins around 4-5 days postmortem.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amongst postmortem findings:

 

  • Adipocere formation is by 8-10 days
  • Relaxation of urethral sphincter is by 24 hrs.
  • Marbling of veins is by 2-3 days
  • Liquefaction of tissues is by 4-5 days

questions.text: A militant presents with rashes all over his body sparing the palms and soles. On examination, he was febrile and lice were noted. Which of the following is responsible for his condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rickettsia prowazekii

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of epidemic or louse-borne typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii.

 

Pediculus corporis (human body louse) is the vector for the parasite, although the head louse may also transmit the disease. After the incubation period of 5 - 15 days, the disease typically starts with fever and chills. By around 4 - 5th day of fever, a characteristic rash appears, which starts on the trunk and spreads over the limbs but spares the face, palms, and soles.

 

The infection can be transmitted by

 

  • Contaminated louse feces rubbed through abrasions caused by scratching
  • Inhalation of aerosols of dried louse feces or directly through the conjunctiva

 

The disease is often severe with the fever lasting for over 2 weeks and is more fatal in patients older than 40 years of age.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Rickettsia typhi causes murine (flea-borne) or endemic typhus. Rats are the reservoirs of infection and the parasite is transmitted by Xenopsylla cheopis (flea). The infection is transmitted when the flea feces is rubbed into the bite wound. The clinical features are similar to that of epidemic typhus but are milder and rarely fatal.

 

Patients can present with fever, headache, myalgia, and rash.

 

Option C. Rickettsia akari causes rickettsial pox, which is a mild disease resembling varicella. The disease is transmitted by mites and the patients may present with fever, headache, and a vesicular rash.

 

Option D. Rickettsia conorii causes the Mediterranean spotted fever. The parasite is transmitted by ticks and the patients present with fever, headache, rash, and eschar (tache noire).

 

Educational Objective

 

Rickettsia prowazekii, transmitted by body lice, causes epidemic typhus, which is characterized by a rash that begins on the trunk and spreads to the extremities while sparing the face, palms, and soles. Awareness of this disease's clinical features and transmission methods is essential for preventing outbreaks in high-risk environments.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain, fatigue, and weight loss and looked jaundiced. Upon further investigation, you suspect a parasitic infection. You obtain a stool sample and operculated eggs in the feces. Further examination reveals the presence of a parasite with a complex life cycle with snail and plants as the intermediate host. Which parasite is most likely responsible for the above symptoms? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fasciola hepatica

 

Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke) causes disease primarily in sheep and other domestic animals.

 

Humans are infected by eating watercress (or other aquatic plants) contaminated by larvae (metacercariae) that excyst in the duodenum, penetrate the gut wall, and reach the liver, where they mature into adults.

 

The adult flukes in the bile ducts produce eggs, which are excreted in the feces. The eggs hatch in freshwater and miracidia enter the snails. Miracidia develop into cercariae, which then encyst on aquatic vegetation.

 

Sheep and humans eat the plants, thus completing the life cycle.

 

Diagnosis is made by identification of the eggs in the feces.

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Fasciolopsis buski: Fasciolopsis buski is an intestinal fluke, and while it also involves snails as intermediate hosts, it does not primarily target the liver. Infection typically occurs through ingestion of aquatic plants, but the symptoms and life cycle do not match those described.

 

Option C. Paragonimus westermani: Paragonimus westermani, the lung fluke, has a complex life cycle involving snails and crustaceans. It primarily causes pulmonary symptoms rather than abdominal pain, fatigue, and weight loss. Eggs are typically found in sputum, not feces.

 

Option D. Clonorchis sinensis: Clonorchis sinensis, the Chinese liver fluke, also involves snails as intermediate hosts and can cause liver-related symptoms. However, the life cycle and specific hosts differ slightly from Fasciola hepatica. It primarily affects the liver and bile ducts but is more common in certain geographic regions.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Fasciola hepatica, the sheep liver fluke, is diagnosed by identifying eggs in the feces, and it has a complex life cycle involving snails and aquatic vegetation, making it the most likely cause of the described symptoms.

choices.text: Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy
It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection

questions.text: A 67 yrs. old male patient visits the emergency department due to rapidly worsening pain and swelling in the genital and perianal regions, with signs of necrotizing infection as shown below upon examination, the patient has a history of alcohol abuse and poorly controlled diabetes, and laboratory tests reveal leukocytosis and elevated blood glucose levels. What is the accurate statement about the condition presented by the patient?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection

 

  • The image and clinical scenario suggest Fournier's gangrene, which is a mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection and a surgical emergency.
  • Fournier's gangrene is a rapidly progressive infection of the genitalia and perineum caused by mixed bacterial flora, often associated with diabetes, cancer, malnutrition, recent urogenital or colorectal instrumentation, or trauma.
  • Symptoms of Fournier's gangrene include erythema, swelling, pain, and blister formation with ultimately foul-smelling necrotic lesions.
  • Correct. Fournier's gangrene involves a mixed infection with both aerobic (oxygen-using) and anaerobic (not oxygen-using) bacteria. The presence of multiple bacterial types contributes to the rapid progression and severity of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy: Incorrect. Anti-gas gangrene serum therapy is typically used for the treatment of gas gangrene caused by the bacterium Clostridium perfringens. While C. perfringens can sometimes be a part of the mixed bacterial flora in Fournier's gangrene, the condition itself is not specifically gas gangrene, and thus anti-gas gangrene serum therapy is not the primary treatment.

 

Option C. Bilateral orchidectomy is generally performed: Incorrect. A bilateral orchidectomy, or the removal of both testes, is not a standard treatment for Fournier's gangrene. Testes are typically spared in Fournier’s gangrene.

 

Option D. Compulsory urinary diversion is performed: Incorrect. While urinary diversion might be considered in some cases where the urethra is compromised or if there's significant involvement of the urogenital structures, it's not a compulsory or routine part of the management of Fournier's gangrene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fournier's gangrene is a surgical emergency characterized by a mixed aerobic and anaerobic bacterial infection of the genital and perianal regions, often associated with underlying conditions like diabetes and malnutrition.
  • It requires prompt surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics.

choices.text: Upper GI endoscopy and esophageal manometry
Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of progressive difficulty swallowing both solids and liquids over the last 6 months. He describes a sensation of food getting stuck in his chest and frequent nighttime regurgitation of undigested food. He has experienced unintentional weight loss but denies heartburn. A barium swallow study reveals a classic "bird-beak" narrowing at the distal esophagus. What is the next best step in the evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper GI endoscopy and esophageal manometry

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation and barium swallow findings suggest achalasia, a disorder of the esophagus characterized by absent peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES). Esophageal manometry is the gold standard and most sensitive test for diagnosing achalasia, as it can identify the disease even before esophageal dilatation and food retention become evident. The diagnostic criteria for achalasia on manometry include impaired LES relaxation, absence of peristalsis, and elevated LES pressure. Upper GI endoscopy is necessary to exclude pseudoachalasia, which can be caused by malignancies at the gastroesophageal junction mimicking achalasia.

 

Pathophysiology: Achalasia is caused by the degeneration of ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus, leading to disrupted esophageal motility and failure of the LES to relax. This results in a functional obstruction, with characteristic symptoms of dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss.

 

Diagnosis: The combination of endoscopy and manometry is essential; endoscopy rules out structural lesions or malignancies, while manometry provides definitive diagnostic information about esophageal motility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. High-resolution esophageal manometry only: This option is incorrect because, although manometry is the key diagnostic test, it should be combined with endoscopy to exclude conditions such as malignancy that can mimic achalasia (pseudoachalasia).

 

Option C. Esophageal pH monitoring: This option is incorrect because pH monitoring is primarily used to diagnose gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and is not indicated in the initial evaluation of achalasia. It does not provide information about esophageal motility or LES function.

 

Option D. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest: This option is incorrect as CT scans are not used to diagnose achalasia and do not assess esophageal motility. CT imaging is more appropriate for evaluating extrinsic compression or assessing malignancy once suggested by other findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achalasia is an esophageal motility disorder characterized by absent peristalsis and impaired LES relaxation. The best approach for diagnosis includes upper GI endoscopy to rule out pseudoachalasia and esophageal manometry to confirm the diagnosis with precise assessment of motility abnormalities.

questions.text: Which curve among the following represents the production of gamma-globin chains?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Orange curve

 

In the given image, the orange curve represents the gamma-globin chain production.

 

 

Gamma globin chain is produced in the fetal period and disappears by 6 months of age. Postpartum which is the pattern represented by the orange curve.

 

The type of hemoglobin variant is determined by the combination of globin chains.

Adult hemoglobin consists of 2 alpha and 2 beta chains, whereas fetal hemoglobin is made of 2 alpha and 2 gamma-globin chains. ﻿

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Green Curve: Incorrect. The green curve represents beta-globin chain production, which increases after birth and replaces gamma-globin chains in adult hemoglobin.

 

Option B. Black Curve: Incorrect. The black curve does not accurately represent any specific globin chain production in this context.

 

Option C. Blue Curve: Incorrect. The blue curve represents epsilon-globin chain production, which occurs during the embryonic stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The orange curve in the provided image represents the production of gamma-globin chains, which are crucial during the fetal period and decline after birth as beta-globin production increases.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who recently lost his wife complains that his intestines have rotted. He believes he is to blame for his wife's death and should be imprisoned. He complains that he is constantly depressed and has lost interest in daily activities since his wife's death. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG  2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psychotic depression

 

The patient's presentation of severe depressive symptoms (constant depression, anhedonia) combined with delusional beliefs (thinking his intestines have rotted, feeling culpable for his wife's death) is characteristic of psychotic depression. Psychotic depression, or major depressive disorder with psychotic features, is a subtype of major depression characterized by the presence of mood-congruent or mood-incongruent delusions or hallucinations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal grief reaction might involve feelings of sadness and even guilt, but it wouldn't typically involve delusions although transient hallucinations can be seen.

 

Option C. Delusional disorder involves holding one or more delusions in the absence of other psychiatric disorders. These individuals' functioning might not be notably impaired, and the delusions do not typically center around depressive themes.

 

Option D. Schizophrenia involves characteristic symptoms like hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech or behavior, and negative symptoms. While depression can be a feature, the given presentation is more aligned with psychotic depression than with schizophrenia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychotic depression is seen in moderate to severe depressive disorder where the individual experiences both depressive symptoms and psychosis, such as delusions or hallucinations. These psychotic symptoms could be mood congruent (i.e, content of delusion/ hallucination is consistent with the depressed mood) or mood incongruent. Delusions in psychotic depression often revolve around themes of guilt, worthlessness, or illness.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 356, 360.

choices.text: Midline laparotomy and mesh plasty
Abdominothoracic surgery with abdominal zipping
Damage control surgery and mesh closure of abdomen
Abdominoplasty and primary closure of abdomen

questions.text: A 30-year-old male involved in a road traffic accident is brought to the trauma center. On examination, his BP is 90/56 mm Hg, pulse rate is 150/min, SpO2 is 86%, and he has a Glasgow coma score of 8. The patient has multiple injuries, and FAST reveals hemorrhage in all quadrants. He was operated upon, and the postoperative images are shown below. Which option correctly describes the procedures depicted in the images? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Damage control surgery and mesh closure of abdomen

 

Explanation

 

The images depict a scenario typical of damage control surgery, which is a minimal intervention aimed at stabilizing a critically injured patient. This approach includes an abbreviated laparotomy to control hemorrhage and contamination, temporary packing, and the closure of the abdomen using mesh to prevent abdominal compartment syndrome. This is done to mitigate the physiologic responses to prolonged shock and massive hemorrhage.

 

 

Other options

 

Option A. Midline laparotomy and meshplasty: Although this involves a midline laparotomy, it does not typically include the minimal intervention and temporary measures characteristic of damage control surgery.

 

Option B. Abdominothoracic surgery with abdominal zipping: This procedure involves a combination of thoracic and abdominal surgical interventions, which are not depicted in the images or described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Abdominoplasty and primary closure of abdomen: Abdominoplasty is a cosmetic procedure involving the removal of excess abdominal fat and skin, which is not relevant to the emergency trauma setting described.

 

Educational Objectives  : Damage control surgery involves minimal intervention to stabilize a critically injured patient, including an abbreviated laparotomy, temporary packing, and mesh closure of the abdomen to prevent abdominal compartment syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following findings is/are true about Crohn’s disease, in contrast to ulcerative colitis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) More risk of perianal fistulae

 

Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis are both types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), but they have distinct characteristics and should not be considered the same. Crohn's disease can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from the mouth to the anus, and is known for causing "skip lesions," meaning areas of diseased tissue interspersed with healthy tissue.

 

  • Perianal fistulae: Crohn’s disease is more associated with perianal complications, including fistulae, abscesses, and fissures, due to the deeper transmural inflammation that characterizes the disease. This is in contrast to ulcerative colitis, which primarily involves the mucosa and submucosa and starts from the rectum, rarely involving perianal areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lesions are continuous: This statement is incorrect for Crohn’s disease. Continuous lesions are characteristic of ulcerative colitis. In Crohn’s disease, the inflammation is patchy, with skip lesions being typical.

 

Option C. Malignancy is more common: Malignancy is more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis, particularly colorectal cancer, due to the long-standing inflammation typically confined to the colon. Crohn’s disease has a lower risk of malignancy.

 

Option D. Often presents with hematochezia: Hematochezia, or the passage of fresh blood in the stool, is more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis. Crohn’s disease typically presents with non-bloody diarrhea, although some cases might involve blood, it is not as frequent as in ulcerative colitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crohn’s disease is characterized by a higher risk of perianal fistulae and skip lesions, in contrast to ulcerative colitis, which presents with continuous lesions and a higher risk of colorectal malignancy.

questions.text: John, a 55-year-old man, visits his primary care physician due to progressively worsening symptoms of difficulty swallowing and chest pain over the past few weeks. The physician refers John for an esophageal endoscopy to investigate the cause of his symptoms. During the endoscopy, the gastroenterologist observes serpiginous ulcers in John's esophagus. What is the likely diagnosis indicated by these findings?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. CMV esophagitis

 

Explanation:

 

CMV (Cytomegalovirus) esophagitis is an infection of the esophagus caused by the Cytomegalovirus. It predominantly affects immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS or transplant recipients. The characteristic endoscopic finding in CMV esophagitis is the presence of large, linear or serpiginous (snake-like) ulcers, often located in the distal esophagus. These ulcers typically have well-defined edges and are surrounded by relatively normal mucosa, which helps to differentiate them from other types of esophagitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Candida Esophagitis: Candida esophagitis is a fungal infection caused by Candida species, most commonly Candida albicans. It is common in immunocompromised patients or those on prolonged antibiotics or inhaled steroids. Endoscopic findings typically show white-yellow plaques or patches that can be scraped off, often described as having a "cottage cheese-like" appearance, rather than serpiginous ulcers.

 

Option C. Herpetic Esophagitis: Herpetic esophagitis is caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV) and can affect both immunocompromised and immunocompetent individuals. It is characterized by odynophagia (painful swallowing) and dysphagia (difficulty swallowing). Endoscopically, herpetic esophagitis usually presents with small, well-circumscribed ulcers that resemble "volcano-like" or "punched-out" lesions, which are different from the serpiginous ulcers seen in CMV esophagitis.

 

Option D. Radiation Esophagitis: Radiation esophagitis is a side effect of radiation therapy, particularly for cancers in the chest area, such as lung cancer. It manifests with symptoms like pain, difficulty swallowing, and a sensation of something stuck in the throat. Endoscopic findings may include mucosal redness, swelling, and non-specific ulcerations, but not the distinct serpiginous ulcers typical of CMV esophagitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serpiginous ulcers in the esophagus observed during endoscopy are characteristic of CMV esophagitis, especially in immunocompromised patients. This feature helps differentiate it from other forms of esophagitis such as Candida, herpetic, and radiation-induced esophagitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely regarding Rh incompatibility in a newborn? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased urine bilirubin

 

Increased urine bilirubin is the least likely finding in newborns with Rh incompatibility. Rh incompatibility occurs when the mother is Rh-negative, and the baby is Rh-positive, leading to hemolysis of the baby's red blood cells. This hemolysis releases hemoglobin, which is broken down into biliverdin and then into unconjugated bilirubin. This unconjugated bilirubin is lipid-soluble and cannot be excreted directly in the urine because it needs to be conjugated by the liver to become water-soluble. However, the enzyme required for this conjugation (glucuronyl transferase) is immature in newborns, especially in those with Rh incompatibility, leading to an accumulation of unconjugated bilirubin in the blood.

 

Unconjugated bilirubin is not excreted in the urine; instead, it is converted to urobilinogen and stercobilinogen in the intestines by bacteria, which are then excreted in the urine and feces, respectively. This process is why increased fecal urobilinogen and stercobilinogen are likely findings in Rh incompatibility. The lack of mature enzyme activity in the liver of a newborn prevents significant conjugation and excretion of bilirubin in the urine, making increased urine bilirubin an unlikely finding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased unconjugated bilirubin: This is a common finding in newborns with Rh incompatibility due to the hemolysis of red blood cells, which leads to the release of hemoglobin that is converted to unconjugated bilirubin.

 

Option B. Increased fecal urobilinogen: This is likely because unconjugated bilirubin, once processed by intestinal bacteria, is converted into urobilinogen and stercobilinogen, which are then excreted in the feces.

 

Option D. Increased stercobilinogen: Like urobilinogen, stercobilinogen is a breakdown product of bilirubin excreted in the feces, making its increase likely in Rh incompatibility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Rh incompatibility, increased urine bilirubin is unlikely due to the immaturity of the newborn's liver enzymes needed for bilirubin conjugation.

questions.text:
Match the following positions of the appendix: (INICET MAY 2023)

 

 

  1. Subcaecal
  2. Retrocaecal
  3. Inside the pelvis
  4. Paracaecal
questions.solution: Ans. C) 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome presents with symptoms suggestive of a gastrinoma. Which of the following is the most common site of occurrence in MEN 1 syndrome? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Duodenum

 

Explanation:

 

In patients with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome, gastrinomas are most commonly located in the duodenum. Gastrinomas are the most common functional pancreatic endocrine tumors associated with MEN 1 and are often found in the first and second parts of the duodenum.

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) Overview:

 

  • MEN 1 is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the endocrine glands, leading to the development of multiple endocrine tumors.
  • The main features of MEN 1 include:
    • Parathyroid tumors: These cause hyperparathyroidism, the most common feature of MEN 1.
    • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs): These tumors can be functional (producing hormones) or non-functional. Functional NETs include gastrinomas, insulinomas (causing hypoglycemia), glucagonomas, and VIPomas.
    • Pituitary tumors: These are usually benign but can secrete various hormones, leading to different clinical manifestations such as prolactinomas, growth hormone-secreting tumors (acromegaly), and ACTH-secreting tumors (Cushing's disease).

 

Gastrinoma and Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome:

 

  • Gastrinomas are associated with increased gastric acid production and can lead to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, characterized by severe peptic ulcers and gastrin overproduction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Jejunum: Gastrinomas are less commonly found in the jejunum compared to the duodenum in MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Option B. Ileum: The ileum is not a common site for gastrinomas in MEN 1 syndrome. The duodenum is the primary site.

 

Option D. Stomach: While gastrinomas can theoretically occur in the stomach, they are most commonly found in the duodenum in patients with MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In MEN 1 syndrome, gastrinomas are most commonly located in the duodenum. They are the most frequent functional pancreatic endocrine tumors associated with this genetic disorder.

choices.text: To determine sentinel lymph node involvement
To immediately confirm the definitive diagnosis in all cases

questions.text: During the surgery of breast carcinoma, a frozen section was conducted. Which of the following options is incorrect regarding this procedure? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) To immediately confirm the definitive diagnosis in all cases

 

Incorrect. While a frozen section can provide rapid results, it does not replace the need for a formal and thorough pathological examination of paraffin-embedded tissue sections. The frozen section technique can sometimes result in artifacts that make interpretation challenging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To determine sentinel lymph node involvement: Correct. A sentinel lymph node biopsy is commonly performed during breast cancer surgery, and a frozen section of the node can be examined to determine if there's cancerous involvement. If positive, complete axillary lymph node clearance can be done.

 

Option B. To assess margin positivity: Correct. During breast-conserving surgeries, the surgeon aims to remove the tumor along with a rim of normal tissue. A frozen section can be used to immediately check if the margins (edges) of the removed tissue are free of cancer cells. If cancer cells are found at the margin, additional tissue can be removed during the same procedure.

 

Option C. To evaluate metastasis: Correct. The frozen section can be used to evaluate if there's metastasis to the lymph nodes or other tissues sampled during the surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The analysis of frozen sections can assist in diagnosing nodal metastasis and identifying the involvement of sentinel lymph nodes during surgery.
  • If a positive node is detected during the procedure, the surgeon can proceed with the immediate removal of axillary lymph nodes.
  • Conversely, if the sentinel node shows no signs of tumor involvement, additional axillary dissection can be avoided.
  • In breast-conserving surgeries, frozen sections can aid in assessing tumor margins and ensuring complete removal.

questions.text: Which of these is not an expected complication of Heller’s operation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gas bloat syndrome

 

  • The most common surgical procedure for achalasia is laparoscopic Heller myotomy, usually performed in conjunction with an anti-reflux procedure (partial fundoplication) to prevent post-operative acid reflux (option B). 
  • During the procedure, the anterior vagus nerve can be injured (option A). Forceful myotomy may also tear the mucosa and lead to perforation (Option D).
  • Gas bloat is seen after fundoplication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Injury to the vagus nerve: It can occur during dissection around the esophagus.

 

Option B. Acid reflux: It can occur especially if the myotomy is not combined with a partial fundoplication, since the LES is weakened.

 

Option D. Esophageal perforation: It can occur due to the delicate nature of the esophageal wall during the procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gas bloat syndrome is more commonly associated with Nissen fundoplication, a procedure for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
  • It occurs when patients are unable to burp, leading to bloating and discomfort from trapped gas.
  • Thus, gas bloat syndrome is not a complication of Heller’s myotomy.

questions.text: Mrs. Johnson is a 60-year-old woman who underwent a Whipple's procedure for pancreatic cancer three weeks ago. She developed a fever and abdominal pain, and her surgeon suspected a postoperative complication. Which of the following complications causes maximum malnutrition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duodenal fistula

 

  • Among the given conditions, maximum malnutrition is caused by duodenal fistulas.
  • Enterocutaneous fistulas are classified based on their location and volume of daily output.
  • Proximal fistulas have higher output and are associated with greater fluid, electrolyte, and digestive capacity loss.
  • Distal fistulas have lower output and are easier to manage, with a higher likelihood of spontaneous closure.
  • Duodenal fistulas receive an additional 1 to 2 liters of enzymes, electrolytes, and water from the pancreatic and bile ducts, making them more susceptible to electrolyte imbalances than gastric fistulas.
  • The management of enterocutaneous fistulas follows the SNAP principles:
    • S: Sepsis elimination and skin protection
    • N: A period of parenteral nutrition may be required
    • A: Anatomical assessment
    • P: Definitive planned surgery.

 

A duodenal fistula involves a connection between the duodenum (the first part of the small intestine) and an unintended location, such as the abdominal cavity. This can result in severe malnutrition because the duodenum is a critical site for nutrient absorption in the digestive process. A duodenal fistula can lead to the loss of digestive juices and nutrients, significantly impacting a patient's nutritional status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancreatic fistula: A pancreatic fistula is a complication where pancreatic fluids leak from the surgical site. While it can lead to malnutrition due to the loss of digestive enzymes, it is not typically as severe as a duodenal fistula in causing malnutrition.

 

Option C. Distal ileal fistula: While a distal ileal fistula can disrupt nutrient absorption to some extent, it is not as critical as a duodenal fistula in terms of causing maximum malnutrition. The ileum is further down the small intestine, and its role in nutrient absorption is not as central as that of the duodenum.

 

Option D. Colonic fistula: A colonic fistula may lead to the loss of stool and fluids but is not primarily responsible for causing severe malnutrition in the same way as a duodenal fistula. The colon's main function is to absorb water and electrolytes, not nutrients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A duodenal fistula (option B) is the postoperative complication that can cause maximum malnutrition due to its disruption of nutrient absorption in the critical site of the digestive process, the duodenum.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of hypertension, atrial fibrillation managed with warfarin, and ischemic heart disease presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset, severe abdominal pain that started a few hours ago. He describes the pain as constant, diffuse, and not relieved by position changes. He has had multiple episodes of vomiting since the pain began. On examination, his pulse is 110 bpm, irregularly irregular, and his blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg. The abdomen is soft, non-distended, with absent bowel sounds. Laboratory results show leukocytosis and elevated lactate. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute mesenteric ischemia

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation suggests acute mesenteric ischemia, which is most commonly caused by an embolus, particularly in patients with atrial fibrillation or a history of ischemic heart disease. Atrial fibrillation is a significant risk factor due to the potential for emboli to dislodge and obstruct mesenteric arteries. The hallmark feature of acute mesenteric ischemia is sudden-onset, severe abdominal pain that is disproportionate to the physical examination findings, such as a soft abdomen and minimal tenderness. Additional symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, and absent bowel sounds, with elevated lactate indicating tissue ischemia. Angiography is the gold standard diagnostic test, and urgent surgical intervention, such as laparotomy with embolectomy and resection of compromised bowel, is critical for management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture: This option is incorrect because a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm typically presents with severe back or abdominal pain, hypotension, and a pulsatile abdominal mass. The absence of a pulsatile mass and the irregular pulse related to atrial fibrillation makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option C. Acute pancreatitis: This option is incorrect as acute pancreatitis usually presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, associated with nausea and vomiting. Examination typically reveals tenderness and guarding in the upper abdomen. There is no direct association with atrial fibrillation.

 

Option D. Peptic ulcer perforation: This option is incorrect because peptic ulcer perforation generally presents with sudden severe epigastric pain, peritonitis, and signs such as a rigid abdomen and guarding. The patient’s presentation does not align with these findings, and there is no direct link to atrial fibrillation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute mesenteric ischemia should be suspected in patients with sudden-onset, severe abdominal pain that is out of proportion to physical findings, especially in those with atrial fibrillation or other embolic risk factors. Prompt diagnosis and management with angiography and surgical intervention are essential to prevent bowel necrosis and improve patient outcomes.

choices.text: Spread of tumor to anterior chest wall

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman discovered a lump in her breast during a self-examination. She immediately scheduled an appointment with her primary care physician for further evaluation. On examination by the doctor this was noticed.  What is the cause for the following skin change? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Infiltration of subdermal lymphatics

 

  • When the subdermal lymphatic vessels, which are responsible for draining lymph fluid from the tissues, are infiltrated or blocked by cancer cells, it can cause edema or swelling in the skin.
  • This can lead to skin changes resembling the dimpled surface of an orange, known as "peau d'orange."
  • The infiltration of subdermal lymphatics with tumor cells leads to the appearance of skin thickening and pores becoming more prominent, which is characteristic of peau d'orange.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Infiltration of lactiferous duct: Infiltration or blockage of these ducts might lead to nipple retraction.

 

Option C. Involvement of Cooper's ligament: Cooper's ligaments are fibrous tissues that provide structural support to the breast. They help in maintaining the shape and position of the breast. Cancer can invade these ligaments and cause dimpling.

 

Option D. Spread of tumor to anterior chest wall: If a breast tumor spreads to the anterior chest wall, it can cause fixation of the breast to the chest, making the breast immobile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peau d'orange is a skin change indicative of underlying breast cancer where subdermal lymphatic infiltration leads to edema and skin dimpling resembling the surface of an orange.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female is admitted to the hospital with complaints of vomiting and abdominal distention. A nasogastric (NG) tube is inserted to decompress the stomach. However, the patient remains conscious and alert during the procedure. What is the best position to place the patient in during the insertion of the NG tube? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sitting with neck flexion

 

This is the best position for a conscious patient during Ryle's tube insertion. Sitting allows for better alignment of the upper gastrointestinal tract, making it easier to guide the tube through the esophagus and into the stomach. Neck flexion helps align the crico-pharynx with the Ryle’s tube, reducing faulty tracheal insertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of Ryle's tube is sitting with neck flexion.

 

Confirmation of the correct position of RT is done by:

 

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • Aspiration of gastric contents
  • X-ray chest + upper abdomen

 

The approximate length of the Ryle’s tube is 120-125 cm. There are 4 markings on the tube which indicates the traversing of the tube through various parts of the stomach

 

  1. 40 cm - Tube has traversed cardia of the stomach
  2. 50 cm - Tube has traversed body of the stomach
  3. 60 cm - Tube has traversed pylorus
  4. 70 cm - Tube has traversed duodenum

 

The length of tube to be inserted is calculated by measuring the distance between nose-tip of ear lobule-xiphoid (N-E-X rule).

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with multiple stab injuries to the chest. On examination, there is reduced chest movement on the right side and tracheal deviation to the left side. Additionally, the neck veins are distended. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Needle thoracocentesis

 

Patient with stab to chest with reduced chest movement on right, mediastinal shift to left with distended neck veins is suffering from tension pneumothorax. Next step is placement of wide bore needle in triangle of safety to decompress the pneumothorax, followed by ICD insertion.

 

This is the correct answer. Needle thoracocentesis is the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. It is a procedure that involves inserting a needle into the pleural space to aspirate the air or fluid. It is performed initially to decompress the tension pneumothorax in the triangle of safety (between Pect. Major anteriorly, Latissimus dorsi posteriorly, 5th intercostal space inferiorly).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emergency room thoracotomy: This is not the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. Resuscitative thoracotomy is an emergency surgical procedure that is performed in the presence of cardiac arrest due to penetrating chest trauma.

 

Option B. ICD placement: This is not the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. An ICD (intercostal drainage) is a tube inserted into the pleural space to drain the air or fluid. ICD placement is the definitive management of tension pneumothorax but is not the next step in the management.

 

Option D. Finger thoracotomy: This is not the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. Finger thoracotomy is an alternative approach when needle decompression fails or is not possible. It involves making a small incision in the chest wall and using the finger to manually decompress the pneumothorax. However, needle decompression should be attempted first before considering finger thoracostomy.

questions.text: ERCP is least useful in the diagnosis of: (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acute Pancreatitis without choledocholithiasis

 

  • ERCP is not the best diagnostic option for acute pancreatitis without choledocholithiasis.

 

ERCP is typically not the first-line diagnostic tool for acute pancreatitis unless there is a specific reason to suspect bile duct involvement or gallstones as a cause. It is not routinely used for diagnosing acute pancreatitis without choledocholithiasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrent pancreatitis: ERCP can be useful in diagnosing the cause of recurrent pancreatitis, especially if there is a suspicion of gallstones or other biliary problems contributing to the condition like pancreas divisum.

 

Option B. Unexplained jaundice: ERCP is valuable in cases of unexplained jaundice because it can help identify any blockages or abnormalities in the bile ducts or pancreatic ducts that may be causing the jaundice.

 

Option C. Periampullary mass: ERCP can aid in the evaluation of periampullary masses, as it allows visualization and potential tissue sampling from this region, helping in Diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • ERCP stands for Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography, which is used to visualize the pancreatic or biliary tree using a side-viewing endoscope.
  • ERCP can be therapeutic or diagnostic and is the best modality for examining the distal biliary tree.
  • Indications for ERCP include relieving biliary obstruction due to gallstone disease, biliary drainage, biliary stenting for strictures and leakage, tissue sampling of the biliary or pancreatic ductal system, balloon dilation of the duodenal papilla or ductal strictures, sphincterotomy, and sphincter of Oddi manometry.
  • Therapeutic ERCP is most commonly used to alleviate biliary obstruction due to gallstone disease and benign or malignant biliary strictures.
  • ERCP can be used to diagnose pancreatic divisum, which may present with recurrent pancreatitis.

choices.text: US guided pig tail catheter drainage

questions.text: A man who had undergone cholecystectomy presented five days after the surgery with abdominal pain and tachycardia. WBC count is 13000 cells/mm3. US showed fluid collection 7x7 cm in right sub-hepatic space. What is the next step in management? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) US guided pig tail catheter drainage

 

Based on the information provided, the best next step in management for a patient who has undergone cholecystectomy and presented with abdominal pain, tachycardia, and a fluid collection in the sub-hepatic space, would be option B) US guided pigtail catheter drainage. Patient is likely to be suffering from post cholecystectomy acute bile duct injury.

 

This option involves the insertion of a small catheter through the skin into the fluid collection, guided by ultrasound imaging. The catheter is left in place to drain the fluid collection over several days.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibiotics and send home: This option is not appropriate for a patient with a fluid collection in the sub-hepatic space. Drainage of collection is required to control sepsis.

 

Option C. Laparoscopy and re-exploration: This is a more invasive option and is typically reserved for cases where the pigtail catheter drainage is not successful.

 

Option D. ERCP: This may be done after collection is drained, to identify the site of injury, but won’t be the next step in management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of acute bile duct injury:

 

S- Sepsis control by pigtail catheter or surgical drainage

 

N- Nutrition

 

A- Anatomical delineation via MRCP/ERCP

 

P- Planned reconstruction

choices.text: 10-year-old child with multi organ dysfunction syndrome
49-year-old alcoholic man with liver cirrhosis with 1 month abstinence
74-year-old woman with end stage renal disease

questions.text: In the case of a 37-year-old woman who has been declared brain dead and whose family has agreed to donate her organs, who would be the most suitable or optimal candidate to receive the organs? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 31-year-old women with renal failure

 

This candidate is closer in age to the donor, and if her medical condition and compatibility allow for a successful kidney transplant, she may be the most suitable recipient for the kidney.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A 10-year-old child with multi-organ dysfunction syndrome: This candidate is likely in urgent need of multiple organ transplantation, and a younger recipient may generally have better long-term outcomes. However, etiology of multi-organ dysfunction is not provided, thereby the long term prognosis of the patient is uncertain.

 

Option B. A 49-year-old alcoholic man with liver cirrhosis with 1 month abstinence: While this candidate may benefit from a liver transplant, alcoholism can pose challenges to transplantation success. The one-month abstinence period is relatively short, and further evaluation of his liver condition and suitability for transplantation would be necessary.

 

Option C. A 74-year-old woman with end-stage renal disease: Given the age of the recipient and the fact that she has end-stage renal disease, a kidney transplant from the 37-year-old donor may not provide the best long-term outcomes. Older recipients may have a lower life expectancy, and the benefit of a kidney transplant may be less significant compared to younger recipients.

questions.text:
You are a primary care physician seeing a patient for a routine check-up. The patient expresses concern about colon cancer and asks about potential risk factors and preventive measures. You provide the following information: (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Right and left colon cancers can exhibit distinct behaviour.
  2. Colon cancer can have hereditary components.
  3. Colon cancer risk can be mitigated by metformin.
  4. Liver metastases are a common occurrence in colon cancer.

 

Which of the following options is/are true regarding colon cancer:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, and 4

 

All the 4 statements given are true about colon cancer.

 

  • Right and left colon cancers exhibit different characteristics, with left-sided tumors being more likely to cause obstruction due to the caliber of the bowel and consistency of stool.
  • Proximal colon cancers, or right colon cancers, are typically diagnosed later and may present with iron deficiency anemia or a mass.
