  • While the majority of colorectal cancers occur sporadically, some can be hereditary and are more common in patients with a family history of the disease, like FAP and HNPCC. Genetic testing can aid in early diagnosis.
  • Metformin, a biguanide compound used to treat diabetes, has been shown to reduce the risk of colorectal cancer by disrupting cellular energy supply and inhibiting aerobic glycolysis.
  • Liver metastasis is the most frequent site of distant metastasis in colorectal cancer and occurs through hematogenous spread via the portal venous system. Tumor size and grade are risk factors. The second most common site of distant metastasis is the lung, while carcinomatosis can occur through peritoneal seeding.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most conspicuous sign of breast cancer?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Peaud'orange

 

Explanation:

 

The most conspicuous sign of breast cancer is Peau d' orange appearance.

 

Peaud'orange (orange peel like texture), is the edematous swollen and pitted breast skin due to obstruction of the subcutaneous lymphatics.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nipple retraction: Nipple retraction, or inversion, is another potential sign of breast cancer. In some cases, a cancerous lump or tumor can pull on the tissues surrounding the nipple, causing it to retract or appear inverted. However, nipple retraction can also be a benign condition and may not always indicate breast cancer.

 

Option C. Puckering: Puckering of the breast skin can occur when there is an underlying mass or tumor. This may cause changes in the normal contours of the breast, leading to visible puckering or dimpling. Like nipple retraction, puckering can result from both cancerous and non-cancerous breast conditions.

 

Option D. Both nipple retraction and puckering: Some individuals may present with both nipple retraction and puckering as signs of breast cancer. These signs may indicate the presence of a tumor or mass within the breast tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peau d'orange term refers to the "orange peel" appearance of the skin on the breast. It is characterized by dimpling or thickening of the skin that resembles the texture of an orange peel.

 

Peau d'orange can be a sign of advanced breast cancer. It occurs when cancer cells block the lymphatic channels in the breast, causing the skin to pucker and become swollen. While it is a significant sign of breast cancer, it typically indicates a more advanced stage of the disease.

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is a liver transplant possible in the case of secondary tumours? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ca testis

 

  • Liver transplantation for metastatic cancer is generally considered with extreme caution due to the high risk of recurrence and the limited availability of organs. However, certain exceptions exist based on the specific type of cancer and its overall prognosis and responsiveness to other treatments. Here's an analysis of the scenarios mentioned:

 

In rare cases, liver transplantation might be considered for metastatic testicular cancer if it is isolated to the liver and the primary cancer is under control. Testicular cancer tends to have a better overall prognosis compared to many other cancers due to its high responsiveness to chemotherapy. If the metastasis is limited and other treatments have been effective, liver transplantation could be a potential option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Melanoma: Liver transplantation is not typically recommended for metastatic melanoma due to the aggressive nature of the disease and the likelihood of widespread metastasis. Melanoma is known to respond poorly to immunosuppression, which is a requisite part of post-transplant care.

 

Option B. Breast Cancer (Ca breast): Like melanoma, metastatic breast cancer is generally not considered suitable for liver transplantation. Breast cancer can metastasize to multiple organs, and the post-transplant immunosuppression regime can exacerbate the spread and recurrence of the cancer.

 

Option D. Active Renal Cell Carcinoma (Active RCC): RCC is typically resistant to both chemotherapy and radiation, and like melanoma and breast cancer, is generally not considered suitable for liver transplantation due to poor outcomes associated with the disease's aggressive nature and potential for widespread metastatic sites.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liver transplantation for metastatic cancer is rare and generally only considered under specific conditions. These conditions typically include the isolation of metastasis to the liver, good control of the primary cancer, and a lack of other effective treatment options. Each type of cancer must be evaluated on its own characteristics, including its responsiveness to treatment and overall prognosis.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy was brought to the clinic due to a slowly enlarging, rubbery, painless mass on the neck, as seen in the provided image. During the examination, the presence of freckles and skin patches on the face and trunk was noted. What is the most probable diagnosis?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Neural tumor

This is a clinical scenario suggestive of neural tumor due to the following characteristics:

  • Presence of a lateral neck mass in a Pediatric patient
  • The mass is non-tender
  • The mass is present in association with freckles and hyperpigmented skin patches (cafe-au-lait spots)

Other possible diagnoses with distinct characteristics:

  • Cystic hygroma: a soft and partially compressible swelling that shows positive fluctuation and translucency test. It is a type of congenital lymphangioma.
  • Chemodectoma or carotid body tumor: a rare tumor that is most commonly present in the fifth decade and is associated with pheochromocytoma. Patients usually present with a slowly enlarging, painless lump at the carotid bifurcation.
  • Lipoma: a soft, painless swelling that shows the characteristic slip sign and is freely mobile.

questions.text: Identify which of these is not a component of qSOFA? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bilateral absent pupillary reflex

 

qSOFA stands for Quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment. It is a simplified bedside clinical tool used to quickly assess the risk of organ failure and sepsis in patients. qSOFA includes three Clinical criteria:

 

  1. Respiratory Rate ≥ 22/min: A respiratory rate of 22 or higher per minute suggests abnormal breathing and is one of the criteria in qSOFA.
  2. Altered Mental Status: Altered mental status, such as confusion or disorientation, is also a component of qSOFA. It reflects the patient's neurological status and helps in evaluating the severity of illness.
  3. Systolic Blood Pressure < 100 mm Hg: A systolic blood pressure (BP) less than 100 mm Hg indicates poor perfusion and is another parameter in qSOFA.

 

Derangement in 2 or 3 components carries high mortality.

 

Option D: Bilateral absent pupillary reflex: Not a component of qSOFA. The qSOFA score does not include any criteria related to pupillary reflexes. Bilateral absent pupillary reflex is more relevant to assessing brainstem function or neurological assessment rather than organ failure related to sepsis

 

Educational Objective: 

 

qSOFA includes three criteria for assessing sepsis risk: respiratory rate ≥ 22/min, systolic BP < 100 mm Hg, and altered mental status. It does not include pupillary reflex assessment.

questions.text: Which type of renal calculi is resistant to Extracorporal Shock-Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL)? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystine

 

Cystine stones are resistant to extracorporal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) due to their hardness. Cystine, brushite, and calcium oxalate monohydrate stones are the most refractory to SWL fragmentation, with cystine and brushite being the most resistant.

 

Cystine stones are known to be resistant to ESWL. These stones are composed of cystine, an amino acid, and they have a dense and crystalline structure that makes them less responsive to shock wave treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Struvite: Struvite stones are generally responsive to ESWL. They often contain magnesium and ammonia and can be fragmented successfully with shock waves. However, when they attain large size and form staghorn shape, ESWL is not performed.

 

Option C. Calcium oxalate dihydrate: ESWL is often effective for calcium oxalate dihydrate stones. These stones are one of the most common types, and their composition typically allows for successful fragmentation with shock waves.

 

Option D. Uric Acid: Uric acid stones are also responsive to ESWL. These stones are composed of uric acid crystals and can be effectively broken down using shock wave lithotripsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ESWL is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on the stones. It is the most common method of treating urinary tract stones nowadays. Stones up to approximately 2 cm in size can be treated with this form of treatment.

 

Complications: Infection, haematuria, parenchymal hemorrhage, and perirenal hematoma.

 

Contraindications: Obese patients, pregnant patients, and patients on oral anticoagulants.

 

Note: Stone fragments collecting in the distal ureter following ESWL are called steinstrasse.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with the lesion shown in the image. He had a traumatic injury to the chest one year ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?   (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Keloid

 

  • The image shows scar tissue is of a keloid.

 

Here is a comparison between Keloid and Hypertrophic scars:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemangioma: A hemangioma is a vascular tumor that arises from the vascular endothelium.

 

 

Option B.Hypertrophic scar: Hypertrophic scar is limited to margins.

 

 

Option D. Neurofibroma: Neurofibromas are benign tumors arising from Schwann cells. Skin manifestations appear in early life, with the development of more than five smooth surfaced café-au-lait spots, subcutaneous neurofibromata, armpit or groin freckling and Lisch nodules.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Keloids are raised scars that extend beyond the original wound margin, are progressive, and do not regress on their own.
  •  They are most commonly seen in individuals with darker skin and may have a genetic predisposition.
  •  Treatment involves silicon sheets, intralesional steroids, laser ablation, and sometimes surgical excision with radiotherapy.

questions.text: A condition requires the surgery depicted in the image shown below. Which of the following is not usually seen associated with this condition? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Absent kidney

 

The image depicts a Roux-en-Y anastomosis between jejunum and liver (hepatic duct) suggestive of Kasai procedure or hepatico-porto-jejunostomy. This is done for biliary atresia. Several other congenital anomalies are associated with it, except absent kidney.

 

Absence of a kidney is not typically associated with biliary atresia, which is a condition where the bile ducts outside and inside the liver are scarred and blocked.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hepatic artery anomalies: Hepatic artery anomalies can be seen in some cases of biliary atresia. The hepatic artery supplies blood to the liver, and anomalies in this artery can complicate surgical procedures.

 

Option C. Malrotation of gut: Malrotation of the gut can coexist in some cases.

 

Option D. Polysplenia: Polysplenia can be associated with biliary atresia in some cases. Polysplenia means having multiple spleens, and it can occur as part of a more complex set of congenital anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image is of Porto-enterostomy procedure which is done for extra-hepatic biliary atresia. Associated anomalies occur in about 20% of cases and include cardiac lesions, polysplenia, situs inversus, absent vena cava, and a preduodenal portal vein.

 

Portoenterostomy, also known as the Kasai procedure, is a surgical treatment for a condition called biliary atresia. Biliary atresia is a rare and serious liver disease that affects neonates. In this condition, the bile ducts (intra/extrahepatic) are obliterated at birth.

 

 

The Portoenterostomy procedure involves the surgical creation of a new pathway for bile to flow from the liver into the small intestine. This is done by connecting a loop of the jejunum directly to the liver, allowing bile to bypass the blocked or absent bile ducts. The goal of the procedure is to restore bile flow and prevent liver damage, as untreated biliary atresia can lead to liver failure. Ideal management of high grades of biliary atresia (Kasai type 3) is liver transplant.

questions.text: Open cardiac massage is what kind of wound? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Contaminated

 

  • In surgical practice, wounds are categorized based on their potential contamination during the procedure, which plays a crucial role in determining the risk of infection and guiding the prophylactic antibiotic therapy. Here’s an explanation of each category in the context of an open cardiac massage:

 

This category includes open, fresh, accidental wounds and operations with major breaks in sterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract. Contaminated wounds also include incisions in which acute, non-purulent inflammation is encountered. Open cardiac massage often involves emergency entry into the chest, which may not always comply with optimal sterile conditions, especially in traumatic or urgent contexts, thus falling into this category.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clean: These are wounds where no inflammation is encountered, and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or uninfected urinary tracts are not entered. Clean wounds are primarily closed and do not involve placement of a drain. The risk of infection is typically the lowest in clean wounds.

 

Option C. Dirty: These wounds involve the presence of pus or perforated viscera. This kind of wound shows evidence of a bacterial infection or major contamination prior to surgery. Dirty wounds are at high risk of developing postoperative infections.

 

Option D. Clean Contaminated: These wounds involve operations on the alimentary, respiratory, genital, or urinary tracts under controlled conditions without unusual contamination. Typically, these procedures involve some minor breaks in sterile technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Open cardiac massage is categorized as a Contaminated wound due to the nature of emergency procedures that may involve rapid and less controlled entry into the chest cavity, leading to a higher risk of infection compared to clean surgeries. This classification underscores the importance of using appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis and stringent postoperative care to manage and minimize the risk of infection

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the clinic after discovering a painless lump in her right breast during a routine self-examination. Physical examination reveals a firm, non-tender mass without palpable axillary lymph nodes. A core needle biopsy confirms ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). She undergoes a lumpectomy, and the pathology report shows high-grade DCIS with necrosis and a 4-mm margin clearance. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adjuvant radiation therapy

 

Explanation:

 

The most appropriate next step in management for a patient with high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) with necrosis is adjuvant radiation therapy. The presence of high-grade DCIS and necrosis significantly increases the risk of local recurrence, even with clear surgical margins. Radiation therapy targets any residual microscopic disease, significantly reducing the risk of recurrence and progression to invasive cancer. Based on prognostic tools like the Van Nuys Prognostic Index, patients with high-risk features such as younger age, larger tumor size, and high-grade disease benefit significantly from radiation therapy following lumpectomy.

 

Management of DCIS: For high-grade DCIS, the combination of breast-conserving surgery (lumpectomy) and radiation therapy is recommended to minimize the likelihood of recurrence. Radiation is particularly important when adverse features, such as necrosis and high-grade pathology, are present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Observation and regular follow-up: This option is incorrect because observation alone does not sufficiently address the high risk of recurrence associated with high-grade DCIS. Radiation therapy is essential to reduce this risk and achieve better long-term outcomes.

 

Option C. Systemic chemotherapy: This option is incorrect because chemotherapy is not used in DCIS, which is a non-invasive disease confined to the ducts without systemic spread potential. Chemotherapy is indicated for invasive breast cancer cases.

 

Option D. Hormone therapy: This option is incorrect as hormone therapy, such as tamoxifen, may be considered for hormone receptor-positive DCIS to reduce recurrence risk. However, it does not replace radiation therapy, which directly addresses local disease control, especially in high-grade cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) with necrosis, adjuvant radiation therapy following surgical excision is crucial to reduce the risk of local recurrence and prevent progression to invasive cancer. Radiation therapy is a key component of the treatment strategy for high-risk DCIS, ensuring optimal long-term disease control.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient was brought to the casualty with high fever and pain in abdomen. He had a history of bloody diarrhea for several months. There was no past history of long-term medications and previous surgeries. The abdominal X-ray image obtained is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toxic megacolon

 

The probable diagnosis is toxic megacolon.

 

Toxic megacolon is a severe condition characterized by acute colonic distension and systemic toxicity. It is often associated with inflammatory bowel disease, such as ulcerative colitis. Patients with toxic megacolon can present with high fever, abdominal pain, and a history of bloody diarrhea, which aligns with the patient's symptoms in this case. The abdominal X-ray shows transverse colonic dilation > 6 cm, which is a characteristic finding in toxic megacolon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Volvulus: Volvulus is a condition in which a portion of the bowel twists on itself, leading to obstruction and ischemia. While it can cause abdominal pain, it typically does not present with the same systemic symptoms seen in toxic megacolon.

 

Option C. Ogilvie syndrome: Ogilvie syndrome, also known as acute colonic pseudo-obstruction, is characterized by marked colonic dilation without a mechanical obstruction. It can cause abdominal pain and distension but does not typically present with a history of bloody diarrhea.

 

Option D. Pneumatosis intestinalis: Pneumatosis intestinalis refers to the presence of gas within the wall of the intestine. While it can be seen on imaging studies, it is not a specific diagnosis and does not explain the patient's symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The X-ray image shows a dilated loop of the transverse colon > 6 cm. The history of bloody diarrhea and loss of haustrations are suggestive of ulcerative colitis. Sudden onset of fever, abdominal pain with dilated loops of bowel in a patient with ulcerative colitis point towards toxic megacolon.

 

A plain abdominal X-ray film can indicate the severity of ulcerative colitis in the acute setting and is especially valuable in demonstrating the development of toxic megacolon. The next step would be to perform a CECT abdomen to assess status of bowel and urgent exploration may be needed if ischemia or perforation is seen.

choices.text: Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation.
Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.
Sympathetic - Impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in perineal region

questions.text: Identify the most common neurological complication following ligation of the Inferior mesenteric artery during abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

 

  • An abdominoperineal resection involves the removal of the left colon, pelvic floor, rectum, and anal canal.
  •  It is typically indicated for patients with operable low rectal carcinomas located within 5 cm of the anal verge.
  • The sympathetic innervation of the rectum originates from L1 – L3 spinal nerves, which form the superior hypogastric plexus.  
  • At the level of the sacral promontory, these nerves divide into the left and right hypogastric nerves, traveling on both sides of the pelvis.
  • These nerves supply the rectum and send branches to supply the genitourinary system anteriorly.
  • During pelvic surgeries, it is crucial to be aware of these nerves to avoid injuring them.
  • High ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) near the sacral promontory may injure the superior hypogastric nerves, leading to sympathetic dysfunction.
  • This dysfunction is characterized by retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation: Parasympathetic nerves are less likely to be affected by the ligation of the IMA as their pathways are different. Parasympathetic innervation primarily involves the pelvic splanchnic nerves (S2-S4), which are not typically disrupted in this procedure.

 

Option B. Sympathetic - bladder dysfunction and impotence: While bladder dysfunction is a possible consequence of sympathetic nerve damage, impotence is not the most common result of injury to the sympathetic nerves. The more typical outcome includes retrograde ejaculation.

 

Option D. Sympathetic - Impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in perineal region: Loss of cutaneous sensation in the perineal region would more likely result from damage to the pudendal nerve, not the sympathetic nerves. Impotence can occur but is less specific compared to retrograde ejaculation in the context of IMA ligation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma, ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery may lead to sympathetic nerve damage, particularly the superior hypogastric plexus.
  • This can result in neurological complications such as retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

choices.text: Third part of duodenum is compressed
Angle between MA and aorta is more than 70 degrees

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about superior mesenteric artery syndrome? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Angle between MA and aorta is more than 70 degrees

 

In superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome, the aortomesenteric angle is reduced to less than 25 degrees, which normally is between 38-65 degrees.

 

This statement is incorrect. In SMAS, the angle between the SMA and aorta is typically less than 20 to 25 degrees, not more than 70 degrees. The narrowing of this angle contributes to the compression of the duodenum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Third part of duodenum is compressed: This statement is correct. Superior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome involves the compression of the third part of the duodenum by the SMA and the aorta.

 

Option C. Surgical management is by Duodenojejunostomy: This statement is correct. One of the surgical treatments for SMAS is Duodenojejunostomy, which involves creating an opening between the duodenum and the jejunum to bypass the compressed area.

 

Option D. Also known as Wilkie's Syndrome: This statement is correct. Superior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome is also known as Wilkie's Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SMA syndrome, also called Wilkie's syndrome, is characterized by an obstruction of the third part of the duodenum by the SMA due to compression against fixed retroperitoneal structures. Symptoms include episodic epigastric pain associated with vomiting.

 

 

 

SMA syndrome is associated with:

 

  • Rapid growth during childhood
  • Profound weight loss
  • Abdominal surgery
  • Inflammatory diseases of the GIT
  • Immobilization in a cast that increases lordosis and accentuates the angle of the SMA with the aorta

 

Abdominal CT angiography is the investigation of choice.

 

Treatment involves measures to promote weight gain like NJ feeds, which will lead to widening to aortomesenteric angle (due to deposition of fat). If it fails, then a duodeno-jejunal bypass is done.

questions.text: Which of these is not a risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hepatitis B infection

 

Cholangiocarcinoma, a type of cancer that forms in the bile ducts, has several well-established risk factors. These include chronic inflammatory conditions like primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), parasitic infections such as Opisthorchis viverrini, and congenital conditions like Caroli's disease. However, while Hepatitis C is recognized as a risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma, Hepatitis B is not commonly associated with this type of cancer. The confusion often arises because Hepatitis B is a major risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma, another type of liver cancer, but not specifically for cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Caroli's disease: Caroli's disease is a congenital disorder characterized by the dilation of the bile ducts and is associated with an increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC): PSC is a chronic liver disease that causes inflammation and scarring of the bile ducts. It is a well-known risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option D. Opisthorchis V. (Opisthorchis viverrini): Opisthorchis viverrini, a liver fluke, is a parasitic infection known to increase the risk of cholangiocarcinoma, especially in endemic regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B infection is not a recognized risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma. Instead, focus on chronic inflammatory conditions, parasitic infections, and certain congenital disorders as key risk factors for this type of cancer.

questions.text: Diagnose the condition shown in the following image.  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic osteomyelitis

 

CHRONIC OSTEOMYELITIS

 

  • Chronic Osteomyelitis is a long-standing infection of the bone that typically results from bacteria, most commonly staphylococcus aureus.
  • It is characterized by persistent pain, swelling, warmth, and redness over the affected area.
  • The infection often leads to chronic discharge from a sinus tract or wound, and systemic symptoms may be less pronounced compared to acute infections.
  • On radiographs or MRI, chronic osteomyelitis may present as:
    • Bone Destruction: There can be areas of bone destruction or loss with possible formation of sequestra (dead bone) and involucrum (new bone formation surrounding the dead bone).
    • Sinus Tracts: Imaging may show draining sinus tracts or soft tissue swelling.
    • Cortical Erosion: There might be cortical erosion or irregularity.

 

 

  • Histopathology: Chronic osteomyelitis is characterized by the presence of chronic inflammatory cells, granulation tissue, and sometimes necrotic bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ewing’s Sarcoma: Ewing’s Sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor typically found in children and young adults. It is one of the small round blue cell tumors. Patients usually present with localized pain, swelling, and possibly systemic symptoms like fever. The tumor often affects long bones or the pelvis.  On radiographs or MRI, Ewing’s sarcoma can present as a permeative lesion with ill-defined margins, an onion skin periosteal reaction. It is typically associated with an extensive soft tissue mass, an osteolytic lesion with or without calcifications. Histopathologically, it is characterized by small round blue cells with a characteristic "small round cell" appearance and is often confirmed with immunohistochemical staining and cytogenetic analysis (e.g., EWS-FLI1 fusion gene).

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that primarily affects adolescents and young adults. It is characterized by pain, swelling, and occasionally a palpable mass. It is commonly located around the knee or the metaphysis of long bones. On radiographs or MRI, osteosarcoma may present as mixed osteolytic and osteoblastic (sclerotic) lesions, formation of new bone perpendicular to the cortex due to the aggressive nature of the tumor lifting the periosteum, called as Codman’s triangle, and a soft tissue mass. Histopathologically, it shows pleomorphic osteoblasts producing malignant osteoid or bone matrix. Diagnosis is confirmed through biopsy and histological examination.

 

Codman’s triangle

 

Option D. Acute Osteomyelitis: Acute Osteomyelitis is a recent infection of the bone, usually caused by bacteria. Symptoms include rapid onset of severe pain, swelling, redness, and warmth over the affected area, often accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever and malaise. On radiographs or MRI, acute osteomyelitis may not show significant bone changes initially, but can later show bone marrow edema and possible periosteal reaction. As the condition progresses, there may be evidence of bone destruction, sequestra formation, or an abscess. Histopathologically, it is typically characterized by acute inflammatory changes with neutrophils and potentially abscess formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic Osteomyelitis is characterized by long-standing infection, typically with a chronic clinical course and imaging findings that reflect bone destruction and chronic inflammation.
  • The given image in the question shows sequestrum and involucrum in the lower end of femur, which are typically characteristic of chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the otolaryngology clinic with complaints of pain and swelling in the right side of his face. Upon examination, the physician noted swelling in the parotid gland, which is located in the cheek area. The patient also reported that his symptoms worsened when he ate food, and he had lost his appetite due to the discomfort. The physician ordered an ultrasound imaging of the salivary glands, which revealed the presence of multiple hyper-echoic areas within the parotid gland. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sialolithiasis

 

  • Sialolithiasis is a condition where a stone or calculus forms within a salivary gland or duct.
  • This condition is most commonly found in the submandibular gland but can also occur in the parotid gland and other salivary glands.
  • Sialolithiasis can cause symptoms such as pain, swelling, and tenderness in the affected gland, difficulty opening the mouth, and dry mouth, especially during eating when salivary secretion increases (known as Meal time syndrome).
  • The stones themselves can sometimes be palpated and can be seen on imaging studies like ultrasound, which might display hyper-echoic (darker) areas representing the stones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foreign body: A foreign body in the context of the parotid gland could refer to any external object that has somehow made its way into the gland or its duct. It's an uncommon occurrence for a foreign body to be located in the salivary glands. Typically, if someone were to suspect a foreign body, there would likely be a history of trauma or an incident where the foreign object could have entered the gland.

 

Option C. Osteoma of the floor of the mouth: Osteoma is a benign bone tumor. An osteoma of the floor of the mouth would represent an abnormal growth of bone within that specific region. It wouldn't typically be a cause of parotid gland swelling or discomfort. Moreover, osteomas are more radiopaque and wouldn't typically present as hyper-echoic areas on an ultrasound.

 

Option D. Cervical lymphadenopathy: Cervical lymphadenopathy refers to the enlargement of lymph nodes in the cervical (neck) region. Enlarged lymph nodes can be due to various causes, including infections, inflammatory conditions, or malignancies. While they can be present near the parotid gland, they are distinct from it. Swelling of the lymph nodes wouldn't typically cause pain that worsens during eating, as described in the patient's symptoms.

 

Given the symptoms described, especially the pain that worsens with eating, and the ultrasound findings, Sialolithiasis (option A) is the most likely diagnosis for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sialolithiasis, characterized by the formation of calculi in the salivary glands, typically presents with pain and swelling, especially during meals.
  • Ultrasound imaging can identify hyper-echoic areas representing the stones, helping in the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient with obstructive jaundice has a distended gall bladder and a dilated common bile duct and intrahepatic biliary radicles on ultrasound. Which of the following will be most useful to localize the cause? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)

 

Given scenario of an elderly male with obstructive jaundice and distended gall bladder, is suggestive of periampullary tumour. The best investigation would be a CECT abdomen (not provided in the option) or MRCP.

 

Correct. MRCP is a non-invasive imaging technique that visualizes the biliary and pancreatic ducts. It provides detailed images without the need for ionizing radiation or invasive procedures. Given the patient's age and presentation, MRCP is an ideal choice to visualize obstructions or abnormalities in the bile duct system without posing additional risks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endoscopic ultrasound: This is a useful modality for visualizing the biliary tree, pancreas, and surrounding structures. It can be particularly helpful in assessing small lesions or stones that might be missed by other imaging modalities. It would be utilised if MRCP/CECT did not yield adequate diagnosis, or for staging of periampullary tumors.

 

Option C. Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography: This is an invasive procedure where contrast is injected directly into the biliary system through the liver, and then X-rays are taken. It can be diagnostic as well as therapeutic (e.g., for bile duct drainage). However, it's more invasive than MRCP and might not be the first choice for solely diagnostic purposes in a 72-year-old patient.

 

Option D. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP): ERCP is both diagnostic and therapeutic. It involves inserting an endoscope through the mouth to the duodenum and injecting contrast into the bile and pancreatic ducts. While ERCP can visualize and treat obstructions, it's invasive and carries risks like pancreatitis, especially if used primarily for diagnostic purposes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obstructive jaundice is a condition in which there is a blockage of the flow of bile out of the liver. This results in redirection of excess bile and its by-products into the blood, and bile excretion from the body is incomplete

 

Symptoms of obstructive jaundice include yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes; paler stools and darker urine; and intense itching.

 

The most common cause of obstructive jaundice is the presence of CBD stones (choledocholithiasis). Other causes of obstructive jaundice are tumors, trauma, cysts, and inflammation in the bile ducts.

questions.text: A patient was admitted after a road traffic accident and later put on mechanical ventilation. He opens his eyes to verbal command and moves all four limbs spontaneously. Calculate his GCS: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6

 

His GCS is Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6.

 

Eye-opening to verbal command – 3

 

Movement of all 4 limbs spontaneously – 6

 

In the case of endotracheal intubation, as given here, the verbal response score is noted as NT.

 

Total GCS score is not recorded since one of the components is non-testable (NT).

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: ABCDE rule is seen in: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malignant melanoma

 

ABCDE rule applies to malignant melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ABCDE rule for the clinical evaluation of malignant melanoma:

 

A - Asymmetry: One half of the mole does not match the other half.

 

B - Border irregularity: The edges of the mole are irregular, ragged, or blurred.

 

C - Color variation: The mole has different shades of color, such as black, brown, tan, or red.

 

D - Diameter: The mole is larger than 6 millimeters or has grown in size.

 

E - Evolution: The mole has changed in size, shape, or color, or has started to bleed, itch, or crust over.

questions.solution:

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic liver disease presents with abdominal distension, jaundice, and pruritis. Ascitic fluid analysis revealed a neutrophil count > 650 per cubic mm. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis

 

Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is a common and serious complication in patients with chronic liver disease and ascites. It is diagnosed when the ascitic fluid neutrophil count exceeds 250 cells/mm3. In this case, the neutrophil count is significantly higher than the threshold, indicating a strong likelihood of SBP.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Chronic Liver Disease Symptoms: The patient presents with symptoms typical of chronic liver disease, including abdominal distension, jaundice, and pruritis.
  • Neutrophil Count: An ascitic fluid neutrophil count > 250 cells/mm3 is diagnostic of SBP. This patient's count of > 650 cells/mm3 strongly supports this diagnosis.
  • Management: Immediate antibiotic therapy is crucial for SBP. Standard treatment involves third-generation cephalosporins like cefotaxime or ceftriaxone. In areas with high resistance to these antibiotics, piperacillin-tazobactam used in India.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignant Ascites: Malignant ascites is associated with peritoneal carcinomatosis or other cancers. The neutrophil count in ascitic fluid in such cases is generally lower, and the fluid is often exudative rather than the neutrophil-predominant fluid seen in SBP.

 

Option C. Tubercular Ascites: Tubercular ascites usually presents with a lymphocyte-predominant fluid rather than neutrophil-predominant. It is also associated with other findings such as a high protein content and a positive acid-fast bacilli smear.

 

Option D. Intestinal Obstruction: Intestinal obstruction may lead to ascites, but the fluid analysis would not typically show a high neutrophil count. The clinical presentation and history would also differ significantly, focusing more on obstructive symptoms like severe pain, vomiting, and constipation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis should be suspected in patients with chronic liver disease and ascites if the ascitic fluid neutrophil count exceeds 250 cells/mm3, necessitating prompt antibiotic treatment.
